reviewText: This is one of the worst zombie films ever made.  The acting is amateurish, the special effects are weak, the same camera shots are recycled again and again, etc.  The plot centers around a research station's staff who are massacred by the living dead (who, by the way, look like ninjas) conjured up by an upset medicine man.  The one survivor is a little girl who grows up and (surprise, surprise) ends up back on the island with a motley group of friends who end up fighting the living dead still roaming the place.  After arrival on the island, one of the most laughable parts of the film happens.  The island is supposedly out in the remote Pacific but yet the main characters arrive on a small motorboat.  Furthermore, the viewer is asked to believe that the three men who are supposedly mercenaries (two I could believe but one looked like the lead singer for a synthpop band) have girlfriends who look like they stepped out of a 1980's mall.  In another laughable scene, the people need help for their boat but, when one of the men sees someone (it turns out to be on the living dead) in the vegetation, he doesn't yell, "Stop, PLEASE!  We need help!"  No, he decides to pursue the zombie who inexplicably runs away and then BEATS the zombie with his fists.  That's not a good way to get help.If you want a good zombie film, get Dawn of the Dead.
summary: Weak Entry into the Zombie Genre

reviewText: This is another Zombie movie that i recommend a lot for the Zombie movies fans, It got bad acting, cheese, and some good gore scenes!!..As a die hard Zombie movies fan, I really enjoyed this movie. So, if you liked movies like Burial Ground, Zombi 3, Nightmare City, Zombie Holocaust,.. you will probably like this one...The only bad point is that it could have been a lot gorier, because a lot of Gore in the middle of the movie was cut by the producer before they released the movie because he tought it was too gory (as Claudio say in the interview)So the goriest scenes are just at the very beginning and at the very end..But i'm sure Zombie movies fan enjoyer will find somethings to like in this one...

reviewText: "Zombie 4: After Death" aka just "After Death" is the third (you read that right, 3rd) installment in the "Zombi" quadrilogy, technically making it the 'true' "Zombie 3." It follows 1980's "Zombi 2" ("Zombie") and 1988's "Zombi 3" ("Zombie 2"). Technically speaking, this is the last 'true' installment in the series that began with Lucio Fulci's "Zombie." It was written by the previous installment's head writer, but as Fulci had long since fallen into poor health, the director's chair for this film was handed over to a Claudio Fragasso (credited as "Clyde Anderson" for unknown reasons) who is best known for directing the widely proclaimed "Worst Movie of All Time" known only as the loveably loathed "Troll 2." He was also an assistant director on the previous installment in the series, which, aside from a few other assistants and a single actor in this movie (the head doctor/scientist from "Zombi 3" playing a different role, here) are the only connections this has to the other two 'Zombie' movies.The movie starts out with a brief narration stating that a group of scientists and doctors establish a setup on a remote, tropical island where they aim to find a cure for "mankind's oldest and greatest enemy: death itself." We're then treated a to ridiculous 80s power ballad over the opening credits that you suddenly realize is going to be the main theme of the entire movie (think like how there's an instrumental version the Duran Duran James Bond theme song from that plays as the score throughout the entirety of "A View to a Kill."). After that we're treated an extended flashback that sets up the movie's basic, albeit loosely tied together premise: a young woman whose parents are murdered by undead cultists and zombies brought about by an unholy mix of modern science, medicine, religion and ancient voodoo black magic, this young woman escapes the island as a little girl and comes down with an extremely convenient case of partial amnesia which she only reveals at a point where it's far beyond helping anyone's situation because she returns to the island twenty years later with a group of... misfits, is the only way I know how to put it.That's right, she's on a boat with your most garden variety of scary movie victim archetypes: the 'Murican guy who likes guns, beer and scantily clad women and talks with a southern accent, a shy, sort of reserved bookish girl who dresses a little more conservatively than most women (but deep down she's not too conservative) and a black guy. Their boat breaks down when they hear spooky sounds coming from a nearby island. Unaware to them, there's also three other people on the island. Researchers who've been sent by the 'Academy' to try and figure out what went wrong twenty years ago (one of them is played by the head scientist from "Zombi 3" as I already said). As I told you, there's three of these 'researchers.' The two soon to be dead ones who are way too curious and should stop poking their noses into the gaping mouth of hell and the pretty boy who survives and is destined to become romantically or at least almost romantically entangled with the girl who survived the island as a toddler. The researchers find the "Book of the Dead." No really. There's literally a book with the English words: "The Book of Death" on its cover, written in what looks like electrical tape on a large white bible's cover. They keep referring to it as the "Book of the Dead" but curiously, its title, as read literally (in English, mind you) says "The Book of Death." Whatever. The one scientist reads from it, opens the door to Hell and chaos ensues. If you want to know more, go watch the movie, I'm just here to review it, not write an entire synopsis.From a technical standpoint, the movie is quite good. It's largely Italian talent, which is always fun, because they're all speaking English phonetically and some bad voice actors were called in to dub over it at the last minute for its brief theatrical release in the States. But the zombies in this movie are quite versatile. They're flesh eaters, yes, but they also seem to be operating on a hierarchy controlled by some sort of hive mind, like the Borg from "Star Trek." They shamble slowly at times, but only some of them, and it's usually the ones who've been in the ground for decades. Fresher zombies are far more intelligent, some can even talk. At least two of them are smart enough to use automatic rifles-- which, when you watch it is really fun to see. It's like "Day of the Dead" but with running, talking zombies. There's an unusual amount of slow-motion, and I know that this seems apophenical to say, but I really think that since this movie is "Dawn of the Dead Part 4" in Italy, and since Zack Snyder directed the remake of the original "Dawn of the Dead" that Snyder was watching a lot of zombie movies (and other action/sci-fi movies in general) to put him in a mindset that told him to use as much slow-motion as possible not only in his adaptation of "Dawn of the Dead" but in almost all of the movies he's done. Cinematography is excellent in this film, for the most part, and for a film of as low budget caliber as this. It's clear that this movie was under production as soon as "Zombi 3" wrapped, possibly even before that, but it was made in a hurry, but it was also made with love. Notice I said "love." Not "care."Writing-wise and editing wise, the movie is a mess. The editing is choppy, the writing is very incoherent and difficult (but not impossible) to follow. There are scenes that seem out of place or out of order, continuity errors are so abundant that if you're going to try to keep count, you'll lose count very quickly. That said, it has a very strong opening with some excellent visual effects that I have this gnawing feeling ate most of their budget. As for the writing, the characters are all pretty stereotypical, the only characters I really liked died in the first scene and were never expanded upon (the voodoo high priest and the unnamed mother of the main character spring to mind) although they seem to have not been too utterly concerned with the story as much as they were with throwing money at special effects. The gore in this movie, for an 80s movie, is top notch. There's a scene where someone gets their face torn off and I don't usually wince at that kind of stuff because (A. I've seen worse and (B. I love watching it, but it came at such a weird surprise that I didn't see it coming and I was like "whoa, look at THAT! They tore her freakin' face off, man!" That and the vomit effects, this movie is BIG into its vomit effects, and they're effective, to say the least because there must have been several dozen gallons of the fake vomit on hand because virtually every zombie either spits it or chokes on it or just pukes all over the place. It's like a Troma movie in that way. However, I've seen a lot of reviewers say that the movie is entertaining for the wrong reason in that it's unintentionally funny-- I didn't find it unintentionally funny or intentionally funny, I thought it was a very decent, solid, low budget yet over the top Italian horror/action movie. That's all I expected it to be, that's all I wanted it to be and for that, I award the movie a five star rating.The DVD itself is gorgeous, as is the case with all of Shriek Show's releases of the "Zombie Quadrilogy," the extras are unexpectedly packed for such an obscure film including trailers, trivia and interviews with a few of the movie's stars and crew. The artwork on the cover is gorgeous, too, and it comes in a solid case. If I were going to look for deeper meaning in the movie, I'd say it's an anti-gun movie, that the zombies biting people and infecting them represent the way gun violence can be infectious in real life, since some of the zombies in the movie are gun-toting and some of the characters are over the top American (or in this case, 'Murican) Southern state stereotypes. The one actor who defines that role (and you'll know which one I'm talking about when you watch it) does one of the best zombie/insanity faces ever in a horror movie, I'd rank it up there with Jack Nicholson's stare in "The Shining." Overall, I really liked the movie, and I think it's a fine example of Italian horror. It's just a fun film to pop in on a rainy day.So, all that said, "Zombie 4: After Death," or just "Zombie 3" as is its 'true' title, is a fun movie if you're into schlocky, cheesy 80s movies. It's cheap, so pick it up if you see it and you're a fan of the genre, there's really no reason to not have this one in your collection if you have "Zombi 2" and "Zombi 3" in your collection. The next movie in the series, "Zombie 5: Killing Birds" (or, just "Zombie 4") isn't a 'true' sequel in the way this is, as it was made prior to the release of both "Zombi 3" and "Zombie 4: After Death," and it was later labeled a "Zombi" film in order to capitalize on the success of the initial three. But that's whole different review for another time. Long story short, "Zombie 4: After Death" is fun, gory and spooky, badly made in some aspects, brilliantly made in other aspects and if you see it, you should absolutely buy it and watch it and put it proudly on display with your horror movie collection!
summary: Unusually good for a film of its kind...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Italian horror films can often be like the old Hong Kong martial arts flicks where some of them are so much the same that it is nearly impossible for anyone but die-hard genre fans to tell the difference. Such is the case with ZOMBIE 4 which is not really a sequel but pretty much an entire new film.A vengeful voodoo priest puts a curse on an island causing the gates of hell to open up. Despite its title, the demonic creatures seem more like "demons" than "zombies". In any case, this movie is equal parts Italian zombie flick and second-rate mercernary thriller. The dialouge is awful, the action scenes are very poorly-choreographed, the music is as cheesy as it gets, and the gore effects depend more on blood than any actual make-up.The walking dead in this film are a problem of their own. Most of them look like undead monks or bad Star Wars characters or something. They seem to switch back and forth from being slow-moving to jumping around like extras on a "Lord Of The Dance" performance. This movie takes a lot of liberties with the traditional zombie movie rules. Director Claudio Fragasso has them talking, firing guns, and doing the aforementioned leaping around. Needless to say, the action of the humans is so predictable, it's nearly irriating. There are so many groups of people that it is hard to figure out who is doing what and where.Fragasso's direction doesn't help this little flick either. What could have made for a tense moment in which a little girl runs for her life while her parents stay behind to be devoured is about as boring as anyone could have made it. The audience is supposed to understand that twenty years have gone by in between scenes without even being told. I guess the corny rock n' roll theme was our warning. And again, I can't say enough about the zombies. They honestly come off more like actors with down syndrome walking around in bad horror make-up than as scary walking corpses. The more gruesome make-up is saved for the ending which is underwhelming in itself. Claudio Fragasso is definetly no George Romero or even Lucio Fulci. This movie is not bad enough to be great, not nearly as silly as ZOMBI 3 or the hilarious HELL OF THE LIVING DEAD. All in all, if you're really hankering for some grade-Z zombie horror, go for it but you have been warned.
Title: N/A

reviewText: By this time the Italian horror film industry was on a major decline and Zombie 4: After Death was one of the very worst from the late 80s. Obviously we are watching this movie to see a so bad it's good movie. Well you sort of get that, but for the most part you simply get a bad film, while there are some moments that are so bad they are fun they are few and far between. Zombie 4: After Death is billed as a sequel to Fulci's Zombie AKA Zombie 2 and Zombie 3. But I think the Zombie 4 title was just thrown on for a marketing ploy.When you have Claudio Fragasso as the director you should know what to expect. He is what would be labeled as a hack. Granted he never had much of a budget, but in the horror genre does that really matter? There are filmmakers out there who aren't good storytellers, but can put together a well made movie. Sometimes it's the luxury of a budget. But in the horror genre, some of the very best were made on low budgets. And they were very well made. You could give Fragasso 100-million dollars and his movies would still look poor.The script by Rossella Drudi is lousy, but has she ever written a good screenplay? The script is just really poor and not in a good way where it's fun. The characters are total idiots and often do the most idiotic things. Sometimes that is part of the fun, but not here. It's kind of funny, Claudio Fragasso is best known for working with the late Bruno Mettei. Who in his own right was also a bad filmmaker, it was a match made in bad movie heaven. And Rossella Drudi is actually the wife of Claudio Fragasso. Kind of fitting they would marry each other isn't it?Director Claudio Fragasso (under the name Clyde Anderson) fails at pretty much every turn. It's obvious he had no passion for this project and it very much shows. There are moments when Fragasso attempts some suspense and scares, but they don't work very well. Bottom line is Fragasso isn't a good filmmaker. He lacks any storytelling skills and his movies are also poorly made. But he does have his fans; he's one of those guys that can craft a so bad its good movie. Though for me, his movies are just often just bad.The zombies look and move terrible. They range from fast moving to really slow, some talk and some don't. Seems like Fragasso couldn't make up his mind on what he wanted to do. Actually the zombies aren't very zombie like. They at times come out more demonic, think Evil Dead and others seem more like humans infected with some kind of disease now think George A. Romero's The Crazies.I understand the budget was low, but horror fans should realize that a budget in the horror genre doesn't mean much. Again most of the all time greats were done on very low budgets. The production values are really poor. Zombie 4: After Death is simply a hack job.One of the main reasons to watch this is for the gore, but the gore is actually tame and when there is gore it's not very well done. The make up F/X were done by Franco Di Girolamo and I was rather un-impressed. He has done some solid work in the past, but he has also done some very poor work as well and here outside of maybe 2 or 3 gore scenes they look really poor. Franco Di Girolamo seems to be very hit or miss and here he was pretty much always missing. The gore was really weak.While, After Death does have some fun moments in how bad the movie is for the most part it's just bad and quite boring. The fun moments are few and far between. I'm a big fan of zombie movies and even some of the very worst I can sometimes enjoy. But I found very little to enjoy with After Death. This isn't the worst zombie movie I've ever seen, but it rates as one of them.I understand the appeal After Death has, but for me it was mostly just a badly made movie with very little good going for it. There were just times when nothing was happening and even the terrible dialogue can't make up for it. After Death is gonna be hit or miss. You'll either think it's so bad it's good. Or you'll just think it's so bad it's just terrible. Overall Zombie 4: After Death just didn't do anything for me. While it does have it's fun moments just not enough.If you must buy this movie I suggest the Zombie Pack. You get 3-movies for the price of one.
summary: Claudio Fragasso could give Uwe Boll a run for worst director

reviewText: Well this is definitely the least entertaining zombie film I've ever seen, falling well behind such questionable entries as 'Nightmare City' and 'Hell of the Living Dead'.  Despite the fact that they aren't really related, 'Zombie 4' is relatively reminiscent of 'Zombi 3', with the jungle isle setting and the emphasis on gunning down the zombies.  I actually kind like 'Zombi 3' but the action scenes in this movie are just so damn boring, to go with the weak, played out effects and lame zombies with silly false teeth that stick like 4 inches out of their faces.  And when it's trying to be tense it's just incredibly tedious.  You're thinking, just eat em, for God's sake, and we can go home.I don't even recommend this to hardcore zombie fans, for a single viewing.  It's real boring.  Or maybe the formula is just wearing thin for me.  Not that I've tired of zombie films.  Perish the thought.  Just that I've watched them enough that the mere fact that it's a zombie film isn't going to get it a drop of credit anymore. No matter what the cause, I didn't like it.Grade: F
Title: N/A

reviewText: A group of researchers at a remote jungle island outpost discover the natives are practicing voodoo and black magic. After killing the local priest (James Sampson), a voodoo curse begins to raise the dead to feed on the living in retribution. The researchers on the island are killed by the newly risen zombies, except for Jenny (Candice Daly), the daughter of a scientist couple. She escapes, protected by an enchanted necklace charm given to her by her mother shortly before her death.She returns years later as an adult with a group of mercenaries to attempt to uncover what happened to her parents. Shortly after arriving at the island their boat's engine dies, stranding them. Meanwhile elsewhere on the island a trio of hikers discover a cave, the same cave leading to the underground temple where the original curse was created. After accidentally reviving the curse, the dead once again return to kill any who trespass on their island. The mercenaries encounter their first zombie, who injures a member of the team.Taking shelter in the remains of the old research facilities medical quarters they are soon joined by Chuck (Jeff Stryker), the only surviving hiker. Arming themselves with weapons left behind by the long dead research team, they make their stand as the dead once again rise. One by one they are injured or killed, one of whom sacrifices himself to blow up the medical facility and his newly undead team members. Jenny and Chuck flee, the only survivors remaining. They stumble upon the cave once again, where the zombies appear and attack.

reviewText: I've watched Lucio Fulci's "Zombie." I've navigated my way through George Romero's Dead Trilogy. I've seen the "Dawn of the Dead" remake. I've chortled my way through Bruno Mattei's low budget schlockfest "Zombie 3." I've even endured Andrea Bianchi's "Burial Ground." Where to go now for my zombie fix? One film to set my sights on is Claudio Fragasso's "After Death," sometimes referred to as "Zombie 4" in order to establish (and cash in on) a contrived connection to Fulci's vastly superior "Zombie." By the time "After Death" arrived in theaters (more like straight to video), in 1988, the zombie craze had pretty much breathed its last breath. In fact, the world of Italian cinema was on its last leg as television began to eclipse the movie theater in that country. Sure, Joe D'Amato, Bruno Mattei, Fulci, Ruggero Deodato, and a few others were still cranking out exploitation crud, but the end was definitely in sight as audiences melted away. Too bad. These movies plumb the cinematic depths, for the most part, but they are vastly entertaining in their inimitable way. I've decided to bump this film up on my to review list because the utter ineptness on display here practically demands my immediate attention."After Death" takes place on a tropical island out in the middle of nowhere (re: the Philippines) where a group of scientists (re: bad actors) attempts to develop a medicine that cures cancer. Unfortunately for this band of nondescript westerners, a witchdoctor's child dies despite the doctors' frenzied attempts to save her. Enraged by this development, this wizard opens up the third door to Hell (!) in the hope that he can conjure up a mess of zombies to dispatch the westerners in a particularly bloody manner. As the film opens, we see this doctor chanting some mumbo jumbo in a cave while a black chick with '80s hair prances about nearby. She's obviously going to turn into a zombie, which she does after falling through a gateway that opens in the floor. Before she reappears, the westerners show up toting automatic weapons. They confront the doctor and demand that he stop his reign of terror. He refuses. One of the doctors blows the voodoo magician away. Bad move. The zombies start pouring out of the nooks and crannies, spewing green goop from their mouths as they rip the physicians to bloody shreds. Meanwhile, a husband and wife affiliated with the scientists flee through the jungle with their young daughter. The little girl escapes with a special charm before her parents die.Flash forward twenty years--we don't know this until later as the movie remains vague on critical plot points--to two groups slogging through the very same jungle in which the abovementioned activities took place. One group consists of a few military types--the toothless Rod (Nick Nicholson) and clean cut Tommy (Don Wilson) among them--along with Louise (Adrianne Joseph) and the now all grown up little girl Jenny (Candice Daly). They're tooling around the river looking for kicks when their boat dies right as they sail past zombie island. Off they go into the jungle looking for god knows what. The other group, a trio including Chuck (Chuck Peyton aka Jeff Stryker) is following up on the band of scientists. These dunderheads stumble into a weird looking cave, find what looks like a temple, and promptly unleash hordes of zombies by reading a four word incantation out of a book labeled, appropriately, "The Book of the Dead" in big black letters. Two of these idiots die at the hands of the undead, but Chuck escapes and ends up with the other group at the house the scientists once inhabited some twenty years before. What follows is pure gory schlock as waves of zombies rush the house while our diminishing band of heroes tries to hold them off with bullets, fire, and explosive devices.I think it's extremely telling that director Claudio Fragasso, in an interview included in the extras' section, avers with a grin and hands held over his face that "Zombie 4" is much worse than "Zombie 3," a movie that in and of itself is considered anathema by many horror fans. That should tell you what to expect here. Metaphysically bad dialogue fused with horrific dubbing and performances so bad they make dinner theater look like a Broadway production jockey for position with low rent gore effects that occasionally rise to the level of above average. Really, nearly every aspect of "After Death" misfires in some cringe inducing way. Let's take the zombies, as just one example. Instead of the shambling beasties we saw in the Romero and Fulci flicks, the undead in Fragasso's effort can talk, shoot weapons, and run as fast as Olympic track stars. What's worse, most of their makeup effects are more likely to make the viewer laugh than shriek in terror. On at least one occasion I could see the edges of the latex, or whatever they used, peeling off of the actor's skin. Oops! Oh well, at least a few of the gore scenes work, such as a hand punching through a chest, a face peeling, and an eyeball gouged out of a socket. Other than that, forget about it.Extras on this Shriek Show disc include trailers for "Eaten Alive," "After Death," "Zombie 3," and "The House at the Edge of the Park." Also here for your viewing pleasure are interviews with Claudio Fragasso, Jeff Stryker, and Candice Daly (she's really cute!). The liner notes and Fragasso biography looked moderately interesting but the font was so small I couldn't read them. So should you give "After Death" a shot? Only if you love schlock films or are a hardcore zombie aficionado. Everyone else should stay as far away from this movie as possible. Until you've acquired a taste for films like this, you could suffer permanent brain damage sitting through this sort of catastrophe.
summary: Schlock filmmaking at its most banal

reviewText: If you take Zombie 4 for what it is, you will find entertainment in it. It is, of course, a poor Italain gore epic. It portrays poor acting, poor gore effects, poor directing, etc. Muct like Zombi 3, it entertains for all the wrong reasons it was intended for....it makes you laugh. It takes place...oh my goodness....on a tropical island! How original! The dead rise and attack some scientists on the island and then some visitors. The zombies aren't your typical zombies; these ones run, jump, THINK, and use weapons. Again if you take this film for what it is, you will find some entertainment in it. One complaint is that the actual title in the film says just "After Death" and the box art says "Zombie 4: After Death". I hate when company's release movies like this. Please put the title of the actual movie on the box! No more white lies!
summary: Like Zombi 3, just not as entertaining
Title: N/A

reviewText: Picked up this disc yesterday after an unexpectedly enjoyable experience with the oft-maligned "Zombie 3."  Truth be told, I found "Zombie 3" to be a highly enjoyable (if deeply flawed) film.  The direction was inconsistent as a result of the Fulci/Mattei hand-off.  A lot of the acting was passable at best and just plain painful at worst (my least favorite being the actor portraying the lead scientist, undoubtedly working under Mattei's direction).  The movie did, however, have enough creativity and just plain insane kill-em-all-and-let-god-sort-em-out energy in the script and the execution (no pun intended) to keep me going straight through to the end.  The same, unfortunately, cannot be said of this installment in the series.  While displaying a level of creativity similar to that of the previous installment also written by Claudio Fragasso, this time the whole enterprise feels conspicuously like make-believe.  The acting is uniformly awful (though that's pretty much to be expected in films like these).  The make-up effects are sometimes good, often times bad and the splatter effects feel strangely muted.  In the interview track included on the "Zombie 4" extras menu, Fragasso mentions the trouble he had getting the film past the Italian censors and, at one point, even claims that the producer trimmed some of the gore effects.  Fragasso, jovial and self-deprecating as ever, admits that the film as it stands is pointless and a much lesser film than "Zombie 3" and he is absolutely right.  If you've already seen the Romero and Fulci entries in the series, then rest assured that this film offers little to tempt you.  True, I do enjoy Fragasso's coherent zombies.  They actually make for quite a nice change of pace from the usual shambling, grunting, groaning hordes massing about.  Still, Fragasso's moments of inspiration are too little too late.  I actually have a lot of respect for ol' Claudio.  His interview track on this and the "Zombie 3" disc are both informative and charming.  It's also apparent from this film that he has the ability to do a lot better.  Basically, "Zombie 4" comes across as being exactly what Fragasso readily admits it to be: a quickie cash-in on a successful horror franchise.  While I certainly understand that even artists need to pay their bills, I really wish somebody would give this guy some money and let him make a real honest-to-god horror film.  The man obviously has talent and it's a pity that it has thus far been so woefully underappreciated.  Then again, considering how many young people sacrafice their blood, sweat, tears, and various other bodily fluids every year in the production of independent features I find it kind of difficult to lament Fragasso's situation too bitterly.  If he really wanted to I'm sure he could put together a great horror film.  As it stands, however, his interest seems to extend only so far as the next paycheck.  While this might make for decent box office it by no means assures a good viewing experience and, in the end, leaves most Italian horror films of this period feeling like hollow exercises in style and splatter.  "Zombie 4," unfortunately, has far too little of both.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you like bad movies, this one is incredibly bad.  The terrible voice over acting is bottom notch.  It wouldn't have been much better in Italian, because the physical acting is laughable (and my friends and I were laughing quite a bit).  Here is an example of some gem dialogue read by a machismo man missing teeth:  "Those are the times when it really counts in a mans life.  When you discover if you've got any balls...or not.  I found out one thing.  When a man is afraid he's going to die, there's nothing he wants more than a women by his side.  And I want you..."  Isn't that wonderfully wretched?!?!The basic plot of "Zombie 4: After Death" is that Zombies are attacking a few people trapped on an island (does that sound like "Zombi 2" to anyone?).  What species of Zombie is this?  Fashionable.  They wear either black cloaks or grey rags with cheese cloth on their faces.  That cheese cloth is to cover up their makeup, which looks like they stuck their faces in bowls of oatmeal.  They can sometimes talk or groan.  They are fast moving and super strong.  Well, they are fast moving unless they are all lined up to kill helpless people.  Then they walk in place for 20 minutes.  Oh, and they drool green liquid.I thought "Zombi 3" was bad.  That movie is an oscar winner compared to "Zombie 4".  If you think Ed Wood is as talented as Steven Spielberg, then you might like this.  If you like really bad movies (there are a few of us), and laughing at cheesy effects and terrible acting, then this movie is for you.  If not, then avoid this film like the plague.
summary: "You're not getting your dirty hands on me!"

reviewText: I actually found Zombie 4 to be highly entertaining. Even morethan Zombi 3. Of course, as you may have expected, this movie dosent compare to Fulci's Zombie, Dawn of The Dead or any other highly regarded zombie flick. This one is a good movie to laugh at and have fun with. The effects are actually quite good, and for the budget it had, its amazing what they did with this one. Its not as bad as you may think. Im reccomending this for die hard horror movie/zombie movie fans who already have 10 or more zombie films in their collection.... but if you;re willing to give it a try, by all means... go ahead!

reviewText: Zombie 4: After DeathReview by Nickolas CookWhat do you get when you mix Rambo style soldiers of fortune, Philippine zombies, a volcano full of green lights and voodoo candles, and lots of fog?Hopefully a better movie than Zombie 4: After Death.This time the writer of Zombi 3 took the reins and proved himself even less capable than Mattei--if there such a thing is possible.The prologue takes a few minutes to muddle through the back-story as a pissed off voodoo priest does his juju and curses the island full of badly dubbed scientists who he blames for his wife's death.  As the violence and bloodshed ensue, one doctor and his wife and their five-year-old daughter try to run away.  Mom and dad get it zombie style, but not before they pass off a "secret amulet" to the little girl.  How the hell she escapes the island while all of the adults have become zombie munchies, no one ever explains.Flash-forward several years and the little girl is all grown up and hanging with a group of half articulate soldiers of fortune.  Oh, and for good measure, we also have a trio of scientists traipsing through the jungle, searching for why the original scientists died in the first place.  These boneheads find a voodoo spell book and proceed to read the "great and forbidden four words of zombie power", which makes a lot of hooded Philippino zombies push up from the "depths" (read: lumps in the ground) of their "graves" to get up and shamble around.Bad goes to worse, the soldiers get killed off one by one, become zombies, dribble copious amounts of dark green goo, and, well, you know the rest of the story...The acting gets worse by the scene, the fog gets thicker, and the plot runs out of steam.  It's the kind of silly fun where someone stumbles across a trunk full of M16s and lots of ammo, zombies stagger and moan, and then break into sudden bursts of badly choreographed Kung Fu fights, candles are mysteriously alight in caves and deserted houses all over the place, and a black hougan presides over Philippino zombies.  For folks like me, this is the cheddar for which I live.The music is the highlight of the whole affair; it has a great Goblin-esque feel to it, and adds a level to the proceedings that might have fallen flatter than usual.Thankfully, there is no commentary, as I'm sure no one would have known why he or she did any of it.--Nickolas Cook

reviewText: This movie is bad.Here we go. Bad acting, jumbled-up storyline, and unneccessary fog. Yes, yes, and yes. We are watching an Italian zombie movie for sure.And then we get gore. Really cool gore. An eye gouging and a face being ripped off. This movie has a reall great opening.And then we get washed down the toilet. The story is bland, the gore trails off after the opening. The zombies are alright for a while. They shamble for the most part, but sometimes they run. What they like to do the most, though, is spring into action like thuggs from Power Rangers. They hop in like jackrabbits whenever human flesh gets close enough. It's funny the first several times, then it gets tiresome.The deaths by zombie are good, but nothing exciting. Not as gory as they should be. Supposedly, the producers cut most of the splatter. That's disappointing.In the last 15-20 minutes, the movie drags. The zombies start to talk and you just don't know why. They were silent all this time and now they're talking. And shooting guns with incredible aim. They toy with people instead of just eating them. What? No.Just when I was about done with the movie, it picked up again. In the last five minutes. A zombie bursts its hand through a man's torso and just keeps fisting it. It was great.Then the movies over with a really blah ending. But yeah, somewhere in the midst of all this there's entertainment to be extracted.This movie comes in a 3-pack with Zombi 3 and Zombie 5. You should definitely go with that if you have any desire at all to purchase this movie. It's not worth getting by itself.

reviewText: Wow....what can I say for Zombie 4. Seriously, this movie was hilarious! First of all, it starts out with a family of a mom, dad, and like a 3 year old girl. They are runnin around on this tropical island (just like all other zombie movies) and the mom and dad die. So this girl ends up escaping somehow. Trust me, I have spent many a day thinking and pondering her escape, and for the life of me, I don't think that a 3 year old would know how to escape the wrath of flesh eating zombies and sail to the coast of a safe island by herself....but whatever. Anyway, some years later, this girl comes back to the island, unknowing that it is the same island that claimed the life of her parents. She arrives with some young girl friends, and some really old Vietnam Vets (or some type of really old creepy guys). Yeah, don't feel bad, I didn't get it either. I mean, what young girl wants to hang around some drunken old men on their tropical vacation? But anyway...zombies chase 'em around, and around, trying to eat their heads, you know, the usual. But the real question is...do they escape???? Find out in Zombie 4....Recomendations: Go see Zombie 3, it's even more hilarious.Things I learned from Zombie 4: Seriously, if you are a young girl, don't go vacationing with some old men. They just end up ruining your vacation. Whether they hit on you or they get their heads eaten, young girls + old men = no fun at all.
summary: Now this is a movie with substance!

reviewText: I was certainly wishing for that half-way through this movie!  If any one thing can be said about Zombie 4, it is that stupidity is not only a means, but an end in and of itself.  That's what you get when you venture in the dark waters of this disastrous flick.  Perhaps the biggest problem is not the dearth of plot (or at least a logical start to finish flow of story line), but the consistency of action and mythology.  For example, almost as if to suit the scene itself, the zombies are super-fast one minute, and then rainman slow a scant moment later.  This zombie speaks, but another one merely gurgles on its own blood.  What do you do when you see a zombie with an M16 machine gun?  You certainly don't chew valuable seconds by staring it down!  And, even better, since when do zombies monologue before they put the chomp on????  The biggest casualty of this film, unfortunately, is that all of the good gory parts have been edited out.  With the exception of the climax, and the obligatory spurts of blood throughout, you really don't see much happening.  Director Fragasso himself admits (in the interview you can access in the Extras) that without the splatter, his movie is hollow-and it indeed is as hollow as the sub-nobody actors he has working this story.  The extras are ok.  There are interviews with Chuck Peyton (a gay porn star [very popular in the Philippines] who goes by the name Jeff Stryker), Candice Daly, who had absolutely nothing of substance to say whatsoever, and the director, Fragasso who seems pretty jaded about the whole experience of having helmed the last two zombie movies.  Here's to hoping for an entirely different crew for Zombie 5, if it ever happens.  Final word of advice:  the Philippines has been done to death, get out of the jungle and move to a different environment.........maybe Atlantic City??
summary: And they say only a bullet to the head will do the trick . . .

reviewText: I'm not sure exactly if this is anything to do with the original zombie movie or down the line its just taken the name, this is your typical late 80's zombie flick, typical story where a voodoo curse brings back the dead on an island and then they start killing and eating everyone living, not that that plot was any surprise, its rather fun though, lots of over the top acting, weird looking zombies, there is some cool gore and blood splattering scenes, this is probably worth picking up if your a big 80's - 90's horror fan, not a bad DVD release from shriek show, decent picture, not many features though, just a few interviews with stars and the Italian director and trailers, film is in in English language.I wouldn't bother with Zombie 5 killing birds, its a very slow starter and most of the good stuff happens in the last half hour and its not hardly got any gore at all and the story is terrible, stick with zombie 4 for a better movie in whole!

reviewText: This movie rips off so many zombie movies it can't even be defined against the rest.  Every five minutes a zombie is spitting green goo (any movie where zombie spit out green stuff instead of blood, you know it's going to be off).  More people are killed by zombies with M-16's rather than zombified corpses who crave flesh.  When the zombies talk in movies, it also takes away from the quality.  There is no real ending to this movie and what does happen doens't make sense.  The cheesy eighties music comes on and the credits role and you're staring at the screen questioning life.  I was dissapointed.I stretched it when I thought I liked zombie 3, but I can't stretch that far with this one.  This ones a loser, put it back on the shelf and never look at it again.
summary: Don't watch this with a serious mentality--or at all!

reviewText: So lets talk for a moment about Zombie 4: After Death, shall me?  I know you probably don't want to, but I'm gonna for a few minutes anyway.Good ol' Claudio Fragasso, a kind of Italian Ed Wood, directs his first zombie opus(he was a screenwriter for the Lucio Fulci/Bruno Mattei "sequel", Zombie 3).  Though he's been rumored to direct scenes from Bruno Mattei's films, here he gets a zombie flick to himself, and.....well, it's a Claudio Fragasso movie.  This is the guy who blessed us with Troll 2 and Monster Dog, and I'm pretty sure most folks willing to watch this movie have a fair idea of what they are getting into.Basically what we have is a group of mercenaries who end up on an island that's under a voodoo curse-that is to say it's zombie infested.  Zombie chaos ensues and the mercs fight for their lives.Fragrasso's zombies don't seem to follow any sort of rules, they seems to come from every other zombie film made.  Sometimes they shuffle, other times they run and jump.  Sometimes they're mindless, other times they think and use weapons.  Later in the film some start talking.  The first female zombie in the film looks like she belongs in Bava's Demons.  An everything but the kitchen sink kinda deal.Fragasso states in the DVD interview that this movie was just a cheap cash-in.  Well, it certainly looks that way, but then again, all his movies look that way.  Italian horror really started slipping in the late 80s, and continued trough the 90s.  Giants like Fulci, Argento and Lamberto Bava started putting out stuff that, while sometimes entertaining, was a huge step down from what they had done in the past and what we knew they were capable of. Soavi seemed to be the exception.Zombie 4: After Death(real title After Death, coz as we all know the "Zombie 4" was just kinda slapped on there like "Demons 3") was a product of this period, and looks like it.  Yes, I gave it four stars, but that's for the entertainment value I got out of it, not for the quality of the film itself, which I do realize is quite bad.  Oddly enough, I enjoy it more than Lenzi's Black Demons from around the same time period.  And I like the tropical island setting and the voodoo theme.  If you enjoyed Burial Ground, this film is enjoyable in a similar way, though it never really reaches the entertaining highs(or should I say lows) of that film.Like Leonard Maltin said of Scooby Doo 2: "It is what it is", that pretty much sums up Zombie 4.  If you know when it was made and who's involved, none of it should come as a surprise.  If you like watching Brad Pitt zombie movies and are curious, I'd advise you to stay away.

reviewText: There is a distinct difference between American and Italian/European ZOmbie films.  In America the zombies do eat people, but tend to look more human and the cannibalism is cut to a minimum.  However ITalian/Eurpean Zombie films go all out in the gore factor.  THus this comes in as the dubbed American Release of the movie After Death, released as Zombie 4.  The story revolves around a woman who witnessed the grisly murder of parents on an island that is cursed with the living dead at a young age.  She is traveling there with mercenaries and friends and end up in one of the doors of hell as she must battle the living dead.  Problem is that there are hundreads of them and they just love human flesh.Just like any other Italian Zombie film the focus is not so much on story, but on the gore and trust me there is an abundance of that.  It overall is very gorey and overall for the average viewer very disgusting. However for Gore hounds this is another title to place in your library, for die hard gore hounds only.
summary: Not for the weak o stomach
